title: Deuteronomy Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who came out to battle against Israel at Edrei?
questions.correctAnswer: Og the king of Bashan
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:1 states that Og the king of Bashan came out against Israel to battle at Edrei.

questions.question: What did the LORD say to Moses about Og, king of Bashan?
options: Fear him not because the LORD will deliver him
Ask for his land without fight
questions.correctAnswer: Fear him not because the LORD will deliver him
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 3:2, the LORD told Moses not to fear Og because He would deliver him and his land into Moses' hand.

questions.question: How many cities did Israel take from the kingdom of Og in Bashan?
questions.correctAnswer: Threescore cities
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:4 says Israel took all the cities of Og’s kingdom, numbering threescore (sixty) cities.

questions.question: What was special about the cities of Bashan taken from Og?
options: They had high walls, gates, and bars
They were all located on a mountain
questions.correctAnswer: They had high walls, gates, and bars
questions.explanation: According to Deuteronomy 3:5, all these cities were fenced with high walls, gates, and bars.

questions.question: What was done to the men, women, and children of the cities taken from Og?
questions.correctAnswer: They were utterly destroyed
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:6 states that the men, women, and children were utterly destroyed as with Sihon king of Heshbon.

questions.question: What was taken as prey from the cities of Og?
questions.correctAnswer: Cattle and spoil
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:7 records that all the cattle and spoil of the cities were taken as prey.

questions.question: From which river to which mountain did Israel take the land from the two kings of the Amorites?
questions.correctAnswer: From Arnon to Hermon
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:8 explains the land taken was from the river of Arnon unto mount Hermon.

questions.question: What was the length of Og's iron bedstead according to the text?
questions.correctAnswer: Nine cubits
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:11 states Og's bedstead was nine cubits in length and four cubits in breadth.

questions.question: Which tribes were given the land from Aroer by the river Arnon and half Mount Gilead?
questions.correctAnswer: Reubenites and Gadites
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:12 mentions Moses gave this land to the Reubenites and Gadites.

questions.question: Who took all the country of Argob and called it Bashanhavothjair?
questions.correctAnswer: Jair the son of Manasseh
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:14 states Jair son of Manasseh took the country of Argob and named it Bashanhavothjair.

questions.question: True or False: Moses was allowed to cross the Jordan river and enter the good land beyond.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:27 shows Moses was told he would not cross the Jordan but only see the land from Pisgah.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua was commanded to be strong and encouraged because he would lead the people to inherit the land.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:28 instructs Moses to encourage Joshua, who would lead the people to inherit the land.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD promised to fight for Israel so they should not fear their enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:22 states that the LORD will fight for Israel, so they should not fear.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Deuteronomy 3:18: 'The LORD your God hath given you this land to possess it: ye shall pass over armed before your brethren the children of Israel, all that are ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: meet for the war
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:18 instructs that those who are meet for the war shall pass over armed before their brethren.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Deuteronomy 3:23: 'And I besought the LORD at that time, saying, O Lord GOD, thou hast begun to shew thy servant thy greatness, and thy mighty ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: hand
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:23-24 shows Moses prayed acknowledging God's mighty hand.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is afraid to face a difficult situation at work. Based on Deuteronomy 3, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them?
options: The LORD will fight for you; do not fear your enemies.
You must handle everything on your own strength.
Success only comes through wealth and power.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will fight for you; do not fear your enemies.
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:22 teaches us not to fear because the LORD will fight for us. This encourages trust and faith in God's power in difficult situations (Deuteronomy 3:2, 3:22, 3:21).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 3 demonstrate the importance of obedience to God's commands when facing challenges?
options: Obedience leads to God delivering enemies into your hands.
God expects us to rely on our own wisdom only.
We should only obey when it benefits us.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to God delivering enemies into your hands.
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 3:2-3, Moses recounts God's promise to deliver Og and his people because of obedience. This shows that trusting and obeying God brings victory (Deuteronomy 3:2, 3:3, 3:21).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment after a trial. What insight from Deuteronomy 3 can help them?
options: God has already given you your portion; rest and trust His timing.
You must keep striving without rest until you succeed.
You should compare your blessings with others.
questions.correctAnswer: God has already given you your portion; rest and trust His timing.
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:20 instructs the tribes to remain in their cities until the LORD gives rest and the land to others, emphasizing trusting God's timing and being content with His provision (Deuteronomy 3:19-20, 3:15).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 3 teach about humility in leadership?
options: Even Moses, a great leader, accepted God's will and did not enter the Promised Land.
Leaders must always be the most powerful and victorious.
Leaders should ignore God's instructions when inconvenient.
Humility is irrelevant for those in authority.
questions.correctAnswer: Even Moses, a great leader, accepted God's will and did not enter the Promised Land.
questions.explanation: Moses prayed to enter the land (Deuteronomy 3:25) but accepted God's refusal (Deuteronomy 3:26-27), showing humility and submission to God's sovereign plan (Deuteronomy 3:23-28).

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship can be drawn from the spoils and cattle taken after the battle in Deuteronomy 3?
options: Believers should wisely manage and share the resources God provides.
All possessions should be hoarded selfishly.
Wealth is the ultimate sign of God's favor.
Spoils of battle belong only to the strongest.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should wisely manage and share the resources God provides.
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:7 mentions taking cattle and spoil as prey, implying responsibility in managing God's provisions, which encourages stewardship and generosity (Deuteronomy 3:7, 3:12-13).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to fear opposition when sharing the Gospel. What teaching from Deuteronomy 3 encourages boldness?
options: The LORD your God will fight for you; do not fear them.
Fear is a sign of wisdom and should be obeyed.
Avoid difficult people to keep peace.
Only share with those who agree with you.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD your God will fight for you; do not fear them.
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:22 assures believers that God fights for them, encouraging courage and trust when witnessing or facing opposition (Deuteronomy 3:21-22).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 3 exemplify perseverance through trials?
options: The Israelites continued to conquer despite strong enemies by trusting God's promises.
Giving up when trials come is acceptable.
Success is immediate without any struggle.
Avoiding challenges is the best path.
questions.correctAnswer: The Israelites continued to conquer despite strong enemies by trusting God's promises.
questions.explanation: The conquest of Og king of Bashan (Deuteronomy 3:1-3) shows perseverance and faith in God's deliverance despite formidable opposition (Deuteronomy 3:2-3, 3:21).

questions.question: A family is struggling to balance work and faith. What principle from Deuteronomy 3 can guide them?
options: Trust God’s provision and obey His commands while working diligently.
Work is unimportant compared to worship.
Only spiritual work counts; secular work is irrelevant.
Ignore God's instructions to focus on career.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s provision and obey His commands while working diligently.
questions.explanation: The Israelites were commanded to pass over armed and fight until rest was given (Deuteronomy 3:18-20), showing the balance of obedience, faith, and active work (Deuteronomy 3:18-20).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 3 teach about encouraging and strengthening others in the church?
options: Moses commands to encourage Joshua as he leads the people.
Leaders should work alone without support.
Discouragement is a sign of faith.
Criticism is the best way to lead.
questions.correctAnswer: Moses commands to encourage Joshua as he leads the people.
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 3:28, Moses instructs to charge, encourage, and strengthen Joshua, highlighting the importance of mutual support and encouragement (Deuteronomy 3:21, 3:28).

questions.question: A believer feels disappointed because God’s plan differs from their desires. What truth from Deuteronomy 3 can bring peace?
options: God’s plan is sovereign; trusting it brings peace even when desires differ.
God must always do what we ask.
Disobedience will force God to change His plan.
Personal desires are more important than God's will.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s plan is sovereign; trusting it brings peace even when desires differ.
questions.explanation: Moses was denied entry into the Promised Land despite his request (Deuteronomy 3:25-27), showing that God’s sovereign will must be accepted in faith (Deuteronomy 3:26).

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 3, all the cities of Bashan were captured and none were left unconquered.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:4 states that all the cities of Bashan were taken, with none left unconquered, demonstrating total obedience and God's deliverance (Deuteronomy 3:4-6).

questions.question: True or False: Moses was allowed to enter the Promised Land after seeing it from the top of Pisgah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:27 makes clear that Moses was shown the land but was told he would not cross the Jordan, illustrating submission to God's judgment (Deuteronomy 3:26-27).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: God commanded the Reubenites and Gadites to pass over armed before their brethren and stay in their _____ until the LORD gave rest to the other tribes.
questions.correctAnswer: cities
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:18-19 instructs that the Reubenites and Gadites were to remain in their cities while their brethren fought, trusting God's provision and timing (Deuteronomy 3:18-20).

questions.question: What lesson about faith in God's promises can be learned from Moses’ prayer and God's response in Deuteronomy 3?
options: Faith includes trusting God even when He says no to our requests.
God always grants every request made by believers.
Prayer is unnecessary if God has a plan.
We can change God's mind by persistent asking.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith includes trusting God even when He says no to our requests.
questions.explanation: Moses prayed to enter the land but accepted God's refusal, showing faith includes trust and submission to God's will (Deuteronomy 3:23-27).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 3 teach the importance of gratitude for God’s mighty works?
options: Moses praises God's greatness and mighty hand, acknowledging His unique power.
Gratitude is unnecessary when we succeed.
God’s works are common and not worthy of praise.
questions.correctAnswer: Moses praises God's greatness and mighty hand, acknowledging His unique power.
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 3:24, Moses acknowledges God's greatness and mighty hand, teaching believers to be grateful and recognize God's unique power in their lives (Deuteronomy 3:23-24).

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who was the king of Bashan defeated by the Israelites according to Deuteronomy 3?
questions.correctAnswer: Og
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:1-3 describe how Og king of Bashan came out to battle and was delivered into the hands of Israel.

questions.question: What assurance did the LORD give regarding the battle against Og king of Bashan?
options: Fear him not; I will deliver him into your hand
You must fight without my help
questions.correctAnswer: Fear him not; I will deliver him into your hand
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 3:2, the LORD tells Moses not to fear Og because He will deliver him and his land into Israel's hands.

questions.question: How many cities from the kingdom of Og were taken by Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Threescore
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:4 states that Israel took threescore (sixty) cities from the kingdom of Og.

questions.question: What distinctive characteristic did Og's bedstead have, as mentioned in Deuteronomy 3?
options: It was carved from cedar wood
It was covered with animal skins
questions.correctAnswer: It was made of iron
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:11 describes Og's bedstead as being made of iron, measuring nine cubits by four cubits.

questions.question: Which tribe received the land of Bashan, including the region of Argob, after the conquest?
questions.correctAnswer: The half tribe of Manasseh
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:13 states that the rest of Gilead and all Bashan, the kingdom of Og, was given to the half tribe of Manasseh.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 3 foreshadow Joshua's future leadership?
options: Moses commands Joshua to be strong and encourages him
Joshua is told to remain silent
Joshua is told to avoid battle
Joshua is instructed to build altars
questions.correctAnswer: Moses commands Joshua to be strong and encourages him
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 3:28, Moses charges Joshua to encourage and strengthen the people because he will lead them to inherit the land.

questions.question: What does the iron bedstead of Og symbolize in the broader biblical narrative?
options: The remnant of giants and their defeated power
questions.correctAnswer: The remnant of giants and their defeated power
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:11 emphasizes Og as the last of the giants, and his iron bedstead symbolizes his great size and power, now defeated.

questions.question: What command did Moses give regarding the wives, children, and cattle of the tribes who had received land?
options: They shall stay in the cities given to them
They should move to the plains
They should be sent to other tribes
questions.correctAnswer: They shall stay in the cities given to them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:19 instructs that wives, children, and cattle should remain in the cities given to the tribes while the men go to battle.

questions.question: True or False: Moses was allowed by the LORD to cross the Jordan and enter the promised land.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:26-27 shows that the LORD was angry with Moses and forbade him to cross the Jordan.

questions.question: Where was Moses instructed to go to view the promised land since he could not enter it?
questions.correctAnswer: The top of Pisgah
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:27 commands Moses to go to the top of Pisgah to view the land he will not enter.

questions.question: What is the significance of the LORD fighting for Israel as declared in Deuteronomy 3?
options: It assures Israel victory without fear
It means Israel must fight alone
It requires Israel to offer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It assures Israel victory without fear
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:22 states that the LORD will fight for Israel, so they should not fear their enemies.

questions.question: Which geographical boundary marks the land given to the Reubenites and Gadites on one side?
questions.correctAnswer: River Arnon
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:12 and 3:16 mention the land from Aroer by the river Arnon given to Reubenites and Gadites.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the parallel destruction of both Sihon and Og's kingdoms?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:2 and 3:6 show parallelism in describing the destruction of Sihon and Og's kingdoms, emphasizing God's consistent deliverance.

questions.question: How does Moses' prayer in Deuteronomy 3:23-25 reflect his relationship with God and the narrative theme?
options: It shows his longing and humility before God's sovereignty
It demands God change His mind
It is a declaration of anger
It is a request for immediate victory
questions.correctAnswer: It shows his longing and humility before God's sovereignty
questions.explanation: Moses' beseeching in verses 23-25 reveals his desire to enter the land but acknowledges God's supreme authority.

questions.question: What is the significance of the name 'Bashanhavothjair' given in Deuteronomy 3:14?
options: It reflects Jair's conquest and naming of the land
It is a name of a Moabite god
It refers to a fortified city
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects Jair's conquest and naming of the land
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:14 states Jair named the country of Argob after himself, Bashanhavothjair meaning 'the villages of Jair'.

questions.question: True or False: The cities taken from Bashan were mostly unwalled towns without gates and bars.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:5 specifies that the cities were fenced with high walls, gates, and bars, besides many unwalled towns.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the LORD's instruction to Moses regarding King Og of Bashan before the battle at Edrei?
options: Fear him not, for the LORD will deliver him into your hand
questions.correctAnswer: Fear him not, for the LORD will deliver him into your hand
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:2 shows God's assurance to Moses not to fear King Og because He will deliver Og and his land into Moses' hands. This reflects God's sovereign power and faithfulness to deliver His people, consistent with God's promises in Exodus 14:14, Joshua 1:9, Psalm 27:1, Isaiah 41:10, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: How many cities of Bashan were captured and taken from King Og?
questions.correctAnswer: Threescore cities
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:4 states that Israel took all of King Og's cities, numbering threescore (sixty), emphasizing the completeness of God's victory. This total conquest aligns with God’s promise of giving the land to Israel as in Joshua 21:43-45, Psalm 44:3, and emphasizes God’s faithfulness to His covenant.

questions.question: What was distinctive about King Og's bedstead mentioned in the chapter?
options: It was a bedstead of iron, nine cubits long and four cubits wide
It was carved with images of angels
It was the smallest bed in the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: It was a bedstead of iron, nine cubits long and four cubits wide
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:11 describes King Og’s bedstead as made of iron and very large, symbolizing his giant stature and the extraordinary nature of God's victory over a remnant of giants. This echoes themes of God’s power over giants seen in 1 Samuel 17:4-7, Genesis 6:4, and reflects Christ’s ultimate victory over all spiritual enemies (Colossians 2:15).

questions.question: To which tribes did Moses give the land of Bashan and Gilead?
options: Reubenites and Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh
questions.correctAnswer: Reubenites and Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:12-13 records that Moses allocated the conquered land from Bashan and Gilead to the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh, showing God's faithfulness in fulfilling the promises to Israel’s tribes (Genesis 49:1-27; Joshua 13:8-32). This distribution also reflects God's providential ordering of the nation as a theocratic community (Numbers 34:1-29).

questions.question: What instruction did Moses give regarding the wives, little ones, and cattle of the tribes who possessed the land?
options: They shall abide in the cities given to them until the rest of Israel possesses the land
They shall join the army immediately
They shall leave and live among other tribes
They shall build temporary camps outside the cities
questions.correctAnswer: They shall abide in the cities given to them until the rest of Israel possesses the land
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:19 commands that families and cattle remain in the cities provided until the LORD gives rest to the rest of Israel and they possess their land, demonstrating God's orderly provision and concern for social stability during conquest, consistent with the principle of stewardship and trust in God (Psalm 127:1, Proverbs 3:5-6, Hebrews 11:8).

questions.question: What was the reason God refused Moses’ request to cross the Jordan and see the good land?
options: Because of the people's sake, God was angry and would not hear him
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the people's sake, God was angry and would not hear him
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:26 explains that God was angry with Moses for the people's sake and refused his request, highlighting God's holiness and justice in leadership and consequence (Numbers 20:12, Psalm 106:32-33, Hebrews 3:16-19, John 13:17). This also points to God’s sovereign will and the importance of obedience in His plan.

questions.question: What command did Moses give to Joshua regarding the future conquest of the land?
options: Encourage and strengthen him, for he shall cause the people to inherit the land
Wait for Moses' return before advancing
Divide the land immediately among the tribes
Build a temple before entering the land
questions.correctAnswer: Encourage and strengthen him, for he shall cause the people to inherit the land
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:28 records Moses’ command to encourage and strengthen Joshua as the leader who will lead Israel to inherit the land, illustrating God’s providential appointment of leaders and the continuity of His promises (Joshua 1:1-9, Psalm 78:72, Acts 7:45, Hebrews 4:8).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 3, what attitude towards enemies does God command Israel to have?
options: Do not fear them, for the LORD will fight for you
Trust in your own strength to overcome
questions.correctAnswer: Do not fear them, for the LORD will fight for you
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:22 encourages Israel not to fear their enemies, trusting that the LORD fights on their behalf, affirming God’s attribute as protector and warrior for His people, consistent with Exodus 14:14, Psalm 20:7, Isaiah 54:17, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: What theological truth is demonstrated by God delivering King Og and his people into Israel’s hands?
options: The neutrality of God in conflicts
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign power over nations
questions.explanation: The defeat of Og by Israel (Deuteronomy 3:3) underscores God's sovereign control over nations and history, consistent with Isaiah 45:1-7, Daniel 2:21, Romans 13:1, and Revelation 19:11-16, affirming that God raises and brings down rulers according to His purposes.

questions.question: How did Moses describe the cities taken from King Og in Bashan?
options: Fenced with high walls, gates, and bars
questions.correctAnswer: Fenced with high walls, gates, and bars
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:5 describes the cities as heavily fortified with walls, gates, and bars, indicating the formidable nature of the conquest and God's power to overcome strongholds, paralleling Psalm 18:2, 2 Corinthians 10:4, Hebrews 11:30, and Ephesians 6:10-18.

questions.question: What was to be done with the cattle and spoil of the conquered cities?
options: Taken as prey for the people
questions.correctAnswer: Taken as prey for the people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:7 states that the cattle and spoil were taken as prey by the Israelites, demonstrating God’s provision for His people after victory, consistent with practices in Numbers 31:27-30, Joshua 6:21, 1 Samuel 30:18-19, and reflecting God’s blessing on His people’s obedience.

questions.question: Which mountain did Moses ascend to view the promised land after God forbade him to cross the Jordan?
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Pisgah
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:27 instructs Moses to go to the top of Pisgah to see the land, symbolizing the bittersweet nature of God's promises—given but not always fully experienced in this life, consistent with Numbers 27:12-14, Deuteronomy 34:1-4, and Hebrews 11:13-16.

questions.question: What is the significance of the names Sirion and Shenir in the context of the chapter?
options: They are alternate names for Mount Hermon used by Sidonians and Amorites
Names of cities conquered by Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They are alternate names for Mount Hermon used by Sidonians and Amorites
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:9 explains that Sidonians call Mount Hermon Sirion, and Amorites call it Shenir, illustrating the cultural and linguistic diversity of the region and God's sovereignty over all peoples, consistent with Genesis 10, Psalm 24:1, Acts 17:26, and Revelation 7:9.

questions.question: What role does Deuteronomy 3 attribute to Joshua in Israel’s future?
options: Leader who will cause the people to inherit the land
Prophet to speak to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Leader who will cause the people to inherit the land
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 3:28, Moses commands encouragement for Joshua, identifying him as the appointed leader to lead Israel into their inheritance, highlighting God’s providential guidance and fulfillment of covenant promises, supported by Joshua 1:1-9, Psalm 78:70-72, Hebrews 11:32-34, and Acts 7:45.

questions.question: What does the chapter reveal about God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises to Israel?
options: He delivers enemies into Israel’s hands and grants possession of the land
He requires Israel to conquer on their own strength
He only blesses those who never fight
questions.correctAnswer: He delivers enemies into Israel’s hands and grants possession of the land
questions.explanation: Throughout Deuteronomy 3 (e.g., verses 3, 4, 8, 12), God is portrayed as faithful in delivering the enemies of Israel and granting the land to His people, underscoring His covenant faithfulness as also seen in Genesis 15:18-21, Exodus 23:23, Joshua 21:43-44, and 2 Corinthians 1:20.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 3 demonstrate the holiness and justice of God in leadership?
options: By denying Moses the right to enter the promised land because of the people's sins
By allowing all leaders to enter the land
By ignoring the sins of the people
questions.correctAnswer: By denying Moses the right to enter the promised land because of the people's sins
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 3:26-27 shows God’s justice and holiness in leadership by refusing Moses’ request to enter the land due to prior disobedience, reflecting God’s righteous standards (Numbers 20:12, Psalm 106:32-33, Hebrews 3:16-19), teaching that obedience is essential for covenant blessing.
